description: Would have struck $500 million in proposed military assistance for Israel from annual defense spending bill.
analysis: Amendment to annual defense appropriations bill would have struck in its entirety a section providing more than $500 million in proposed addtional military assistance to Israel. The amendment failed 6-422 in a vote on 7/10/25.

description: The key House resolution opposing unauthorized war with Iran.
analysis: This legislation is critical for preventing U.S. involvement in war with Iran, particularly in light of the Trump administration's strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities on June 21, 2025, during the 12-day war between Iran and Israel. The bill also serves as a strong messaging tool within Congress and the wider public that there is no military solution to resolving the nuclear issue with Iran.

description: A helpful House resolution opposing war with Iran, though introduced after the Massie-Khanna resolution.
analysis: This resolution, also drafted in the aftermath of the 12-day war between Iran and Israel, is grounded in the same core constitutional concern of asserting congressional war powers in order to prevent war with Iran, just like the Massie-Khanna version. It does however include an exception for enabling Armed Forces to "defend the United States or an ally or partner of the United States." The concern with this exception is that it could be easily manipulated to justify acts of aggression initiated by Israel, a key ally and partner of the United States, against Iran, particularly when there may not necessarily a legitimate threat. These were the circumstances that led to Israel's initial bombing of Iran in June 2025 in the first place.

description: Doubles down on failed maximum pressure policies that primarily hurt ordinary Iranian civilians.
analysis: This bill would impose new sanctions on actors with minimal connection to trade related to Iranian oil. Critically, the bill would offer minimal discretion to the President on sanctions policy, and would require an act of Congress to halt after 2029, making it significantly more difficult for a successor administration to use existing leverage to conduct diplomacy or sustain any agreement struck in the coming years.

column: H.R.1576 — Alien Land Law House Bill
display_name: H.R.1576 — Alien Land Law House Bill
description: Discriminatory bill would seek to restrict the ability of Iranian nationals and other groups from purchasing agricultural property.
analysis: Pushes to ban agricultural transactions involving foreign nationals of China, North Korea, Russia and Iran.

description: Whereas most sanctions bills "sunset," or expire, this bill would terminate the sunset on a core Iran sanction.
analysis: This legislation is wholly unnecessary. Its sole purpose is to eliminate a sunset in the Iran Sanctions Act - core sanctions targeting Iran’s energy sector - that is not due to expire until December 31, 2026. While provisions of the Iran Sanctions Act were waived under the Iran nuclear deal for a brief period, it has been extended twice already since its original passage in 1996. U.S. leverage will not be enhanced by H.R. 1800, and there is risk that its passage could worsen an already complicated/absent negotiating environment.

description: Threatens the right of Iranian Americans and others to travel to Iran to visit family and friends.
analysis: Directs the State Department to consider criminalizing travel to Iran on a U.S. passport, which could be punished with years in jail. While many Iranians who travel to Iran do so on an Iranian passport, such as step could represent a slippery slope to harsher restrictions and harassment of community members.

description: Key House legislation to block the sale of weaponry to Israel that would be used in war crimes.
analysis: Prohibits the sale, transfer or export to Israel of various offensive weapons systems, barring satisfactory written assurances that such weapons systems would be used in line with U.S. and international human rights law.

description: Pro-war bill seeks to provide Israel U.S. weaponry so that it can independently bomb deeply-buried sites in Iran, or elsewhere.
analysis: Introduced in the aftermath of the 12-day war between Iran and Israel, this bill essentially expresses support for the nuclear-related justifications under which Israel initiated its illegal attack against Iran in June 2025, killing hundreds of civilians and affirms support for such an approach should Israel choose to do so again in the future.

description: Repeals an old law that could be abused to arrest and dep foreign nationals from adversarial nations.
analysis: Repeals the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which is an old law that empowers the President to detain and deport foreign nationals during wartime or amid "imminent" threat, which the current administration has sought to use in justification of its arrests and deportations of foreign nationals.

description: Bill would overturn the travel ban and guard against future discriminatory bans.
analysis: Would terminate President Trump's travel ban and make it far more difficult for any administration to impose bans based on national origin in the future.

description: MEK-endorsed resolution includes veiled language endorsing the MEK leader Maryam Rajavi's plan for Iran.
analysis: This bill is directly affiliated with the Mujahedeen-e-Khalq (MEK), which was a formerly designated terrorist organization which has operated as a cult known for committing gross human rights violations against its members. This resolution, introduced nearly every single Congress, merely endorses Maryam Rajavi, the MEK's leader -- who is directly referenced in the bill's text -- while effectively doing nothing to actually provide tangible support and solutions for the people of Iran.

column: H.Res.521 — Supporting Israel war on Iran
display_name: H.Res.521 — Supporting Israel war on Iran
description: Insulting resolution endorses Israel's attacks on Iran, ignores Iranian casualties.
analysis: This resolution expresses support for Israel's bombing campaign inside Iran in June 2025, completely ignoring the hundreds of Iranian civilians who were killed in the attacks initiated by Israel.

description: Whereas most sanctions bills "sunset," or expire, this bill would terminate the sunset on a core Iran sanction.
analysis: This legislation is wholly unnecessary. Its sole purpose is to eliminate a sunset in the Iran Sanctions Act - core sanctions targeting Iran’s energy sector - that is not due to expire until December 31, 2026. While provisions of the Iran Sanctions Act were waived under the Iran nuclear deal for a brief period, it has been extended twice already since its original passage in 1996. U.S. leverage will not be enhanced by this bill, and there is risk that its passage could worsen an already complicated/absent negotiating environment.

description: Repeals an old law that could be abused to arrest and dep foreign nationals from adversarial nations.
analysis: Repeals the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which is an old law that empowers the President to detain and deport foreign nationals during wartime or amid "imminent" threat, which the current administration has sought to use in justification of its arrests and deportations of foreign nationals.

column: S.197 — Alien Land Law Senate Bill
display_name: S.197 — Alien Land Law Senate Bill
description: Bill risks violating civil rights by triggering harsh scrutiny of Iranians and others seeking to make property purchases.
analysis: Would seek to limit property transactions involving actors linked to China, North Korea, Russia and Iran across a huge swathe of the United States, which risks leading to either direct or indirect real estate discrimination.

column: S.2087 — No War Against Iran Act
display_name: S.2087 — No War Against Iran Act
description: Prohibits funds from being used in an unauthorized war with Iran.
analysis: This bill is essential in actually working to preempt military action against Iran, while War Powers Resolutions are often raised once military action has already been pursued. A bill like this, along with a solid War Powers Resolution go hand in hand in creating a strong legislative precedent for preventing any kind of war/military confrontation with Iran.

description: Discriminatory bill would ban Iranians and other nationals from securing visas to study in the United States.
analysis: Would ban students from adversarial nations - including China, Cuba, Iran, North Korea, Russia and Venezuela - from securing student visas.

description: Bill would overturn the travel ban and guard against future discriminatory bans.
analysis: Would terminate President Trump's travel ban and make it far more difficult for any administration to impose bans based on national origin in the future.

description: Doubles down on failed maximum pressure policies that primarily hurt ordinary Iranian civilians.
analysis: This bill would impose new sanctions on actors with minimal connection to trade related to Iranian oil. Critically, the bill would offer minimal discretion to the President on sanctions policy, and would require an act of Congress to halt after 2029, making it significantly more difficult for a successor administration to use existing leverage to conduct diplomacy or sustain any agreement struck in the coming years.

column: S.J.Res.26 — JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #2
display_name: S.J.Res.26 — JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #2
short_title: JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #2
description: Would block 250 & 500 pound bombs for Israel that have been used to commit war crimes. Vote fails 15-83 on 4/3/25.
analysis: This joint resolution would have blocked the sale of 250 and 500 pound bombs to Israel, along with associated guidance kits, which human rights authorities have documented as having been used by Israel to commit war crimes. Vote fails 15-83 on 4/3/25.

column: S.J.Res.33 — JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #1
display_name: S.J.Res.33 — JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #1
short_title: JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #1
description: Would block 2,000 pound bombs for Israel that have been used to commit war crimes. Vote fails 15-82 on 4/3/25.
analysis: This joint resolution would have blocked the sale of more than 40,000 2,000 pound bombs to Israel, which human rights authorities have documented as having been used by Israel to commit war crimes. Vote fails 15-82 on 4/3/25.

column: S.J.Res.34 — JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #4
display_name: S.J.Res.34 — JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #4
short_title: JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #4
description: Would block 1,000 pound bombs for Israel that have been used to commit war crimes. Majority of Democrats in Senate support, but vote fails 24-73 on 7/30/25.
analysis: This joint resolution would have blocked the sale of 1,000 pound bombs and guidance kits to Israel, which human rights authorities have documented as having been used by Israel to commit war crimes. Majority of Democrats in Senate support, but vote fails 24-73 on 7/30/25.

column: S.J.Res.41 — JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #3
display_name: S.J.Res.41 — JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #3
short_title: JRD to Block Weapons to Israel #3
description: Would block rifles for Israel that would be used to commit war crimes. Majority of Democrats in Senate support, but vote fails 27-70 on 7/30/25.
analysis: This joint resolution would have blocked the sale of tens of thousands of automatic weapons to the state of Israel, overseen by the extremist minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, and fueling the violence of Israeli settlers in the West Bank.  Majority of Democrats in Senate support, but vote fails 27-70 on 7/30/25.

description: The key Senate resolution opposing unauthorized war with Iran. Voted down 47-53 on 6/27/25.
analysis: This legislation is critical for preventing U.S. involvement in war with Iran, particularly in light of the Trump administration's strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities on June 21, 2025, during the 12-day war between Iran and Israel. The bill also serves as a strong messaging tool within Congress and the wider public that there is no military solution to resolving the nuclear issue with Iran. While this measure did not pass during its attempted vote, a notable number of Democrats voted in favor of the resolution.

display_name: Banning Travel to Iran Committee Vote
